description: FirePOWER is the power of the next generation IPS/ firewall that runs on oneâ€™s managed devices and defense center and FireSIGHT is a passive technology that scans a network and gathers information about users, hosts and applications. Viewers will learn about Cisco FirePOWER (formerly SourceFIRE) and how it can be employed to secure a network. Upon completion of this series, you will be able to identify the various features of Cisco FirePOWER, the FireSIGHT Management Center and FirePOWER AMP. You will also be able to configure FireSIGHT policies to enforce your company's security policy to all traffic on your network.
name: FirePOWER with Advanced FireSIGHT Administration
subtitle: SSFIPS

episodes.description:
Viewers will learn about Cisco FirePOWER (formerly SourceFIRE)
and how it can be employed to secure a network. Upon 
completion of this series, you will be able to identify the
various features of Cisco FirePOWER, the FireSIGHT Management
Center and FirePOWER AMP. You will also be able to configure
FireSIGHT policies to enforce your company's security policy
to all traffic on your network.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.124 --> 00:00:07.207
[MUSIC]

2

In this video we're gonna take a look at
the Cisco FirePower show coming up on

3

4

Now if you haven't heard of FirePower,
it's a pretty exciting product,

5

one that we're jazzed about.

6

And I know I'm especially excited because

7

10
00:00:33.070 --> 00:00:35.111

11
00:00:35.111 --> 00:00:38.308
It's quite the mouthful, but
it is quite a good read.

12
00:00:38.308 --> 00:00:40.269
We've got Todd Lanlier here in the studio,
I know I'm excited.

13
00:00:40.269 --> 00:00:41.825
Todd thank you for being with us.

14
00:00:41.825 --> 00:00:43.868
>> Fantastic, great to be here.

15

We have the most exciting product that
Cisco's released in years, right.

16

So Cisco bought SourceFire

17
00:00:51.278 --> 00:00:54.901
And lots of money,
they invest lots of money.

18

And we're gonna see this product in pretty

19

We certainly,
they have them on their ASA's now.

20
00:01:03.528 --> 00:01:05.664
And that's where I work mostly with them.

21
00:01:05.664 --> 00:01:06.825
But they also have the appliances.

22
00:01:06.825 --> 00:01:09.798
But we're gonna see this, they're gonna
pretty much push this out on all parts.

23
00:01:09.798 --> 00:01:12.746
Because this is such
a phenomenal security product.

24
00:01:12.746 --> 00:01:16.322
[COUGH] I wanna say right now
that I get excited about it.

25

I wanna make sure you understand
I don't work for Cisco.

26
00:01:18.500 --> 00:01:19.260
I don't speak for Cisco.

27
00:01:19.260 --> 00:01:20.453
And they are not paying me.

28
00:01:20.453 --> 00:01:21.196
Boy, I wish they were.

29
00:01:21.196 --> 00:01:23.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But they are not.

30
00:01:23.260 --> 00:01:24.580
So I get excited about it.

31
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:25.410
I do a lot of consulting.

32
00:01:25.410 --> 00:01:27.210
I do a lot of training with it.

33
00:01:27.210 --> 00:01:28.404
I've got other consulting jobs.

34
00:01:28.404 --> 00:01:32.340
But on the security front, this is the
most exciting product I've seen in years.

35
00:01:32.340 --> 00:01:33.832
And it works phenomenally.

36
00:01:33.832 --> 00:01:35.737
Really what it is, it's snort, right.

37
00:01:35.737 --> 00:01:39.875
So we've got the power of snort
with the intuitive gooey on top.

38
00:01:39.875 --> 00:01:41.315
Why don't we go ahead and
take a look at that.

39
00:01:41.315 --> 00:01:44.287
And I'll show you some of the power
of what we're going to go

40
00:01:44.287 --> 00:01:45.721
through in our series here.

41
00:01:45.721 --> 00:01:49.638
So nonetheless, here we are looking at
something called FireSIGHT management

42
00:01:49.638 --> 00:01:52.215
center, or
also referred to as the defense center.

43
00:01:52.215 --> 00:01:54.258
And I refer to it a lot
as on old school guy.

44
00:01:54.258 --> 00:01:58.761
But the fact is, is we're looking at here
and this isn't really a great screen.

45
00:01:58.761 --> 00:02:00.810
You don't really wanna
see this screen at work.

46
00:02:00.810 --> 00:02:03.240
Because this is a lot
of attacks occurring.

47
00:02:03.240 --> 00:02:05.330
So this is a demo, and
basically it's saying.

48
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:07.100
Hey, we're attacking this constantly.

49
00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:10.330
Those red lines are my attacks,
lose my data.

50
00:02:10.330 --> 00:02:14.330
It more looked like, let me show you
a real network that I'm working on here.

51
00:02:14.330 --> 00:02:15.772
It more looked like something like this.

52
00:02:15.772 --> 00:02:20.088
Attacks, we don't have very many and
are ideas are something like this.

53
00:02:20.088 --> 00:02:22.439
In this case here because
we're doing a demo.

54
00:02:22.439 --> 00:02:23.531
We want to see a lot of attacks.

55
00:02:23.531 --> 00:02:26.180
So we can play with it and
see what's going on.

56
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:27.990
In this case here,
I'm gonna come down here.

57
00:02:27.990 --> 00:02:29.900
And I say, look I'm seeing malware.

58
00:02:29.900 --> 00:02:32.669
And do you think malware
is important today, Don?

59
00:02:32.669 --> 00:02:35.548
>> I don't think so, Tom,
I mean I'm on a Mac, right.

60
00:02:35.548 --> 00:02:36.593
So I don't have malware problems, do I?

61
00:02:36.593 --> 00:02:38.520
>> No, I don't think so.

62
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:40.075
But I did see you put in
your credit card earlier.

63
00:02:40.075 --> 00:02:41.353
So you can get your files back.

64
00:02:41.353 --> 00:02:46.312
>> Absolutely, it said I was encrypted,
I didn't want that, right?

65
00:02:46.312 --> 00:02:47.636
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, but

66
00:02:47.636 --> 00:02:50.790
don't you think you
should've called the FBI?

67
00:02:50.790 --> 00:02:54.473
>> Our taxpayer dollars do go to them
to help us out of situations like that.

68
00:02:54.473 --> 00:02:57.585
Are you hinting at the fact
that they don't do that?

69
00:02:57.585 --> 00:02:59.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well I don't know.

70
00:02:59.470 --> 00:03:03.313
I saw something on the news the other day,
and I was like.

71
00:03:03.313 --> 00:03:05.730
Well, I find this fascinating.

72
00:03:05.730 --> 00:03:09.800
So let's go ahead and take a look at
what the FBI thinks about malware.

73
00:03:09.800 --> 00:03:11.420
And what comes in malware?

74
00:03:11.420 --> 00:03:12.621
Something called ransomware.

75
00:03:12.621 --> 00:03:14.455
This is just a piece of it, isn't it?

76
00:03:14.455 --> 00:03:16.972
And in this ransomware,
what is the FBI saying here?

77
00:03:16.972 --> 00:03:19.549
The FBI says,
well if you read through the article.

78
00:03:19.549 --> 00:03:21.477
They say,
well if everyone just pays the ransom.

79
00:03:21.477 --> 00:03:24.710
The prices are coming down because so
many people are paying it.

80
00:03:24.710 --> 00:03:28.400
And it's easier than trying to pay,
it's less expensive than sending it out to

81
00:03:28.400 --> 00:03:31.600
a repair shop to try to
get your files back.

82
00:03:31.600 --> 00:03:35.080
So he just paid his $89.95 and
he got his files unlocked.

83
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:37.049
We're sitting here, so
is malware important?

84
00:03:37.049 --> 00:03:37.699
Sure it is.

85
00:03:37.699 --> 00:03:40.207
Because if this happened
to you in your corporation.

86
00:03:40.207 --> 00:03:43.055
They could be charging hundreds
of thousands of dollars.

87
00:03:43.055 --> 00:03:44.290
>> And just think about,

88
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:48.010
it was just a few months ago that
Sony Pictures got involved in this.

89
00:03:48.010 --> 00:03:50.750
Where all of their
machines got locked down.

90
00:03:50.750 --> 00:03:54.556
The whole company, the motion picture side
of it was basically out of business for

91
00:03:54.556 --> 00:03:56.836
weeks before they managed
to recover from that.

92
00:03:56.836 --> 00:03:58.414
Imagine that happening to your company,
and

93
00:03:58.414 --> 00:04:00.458
the amount of money you would
lose by having that offline.

94
00:04:00.458 --> 00:04:02.368
>> Yeah.
>> Wouldn't it be nice if we could stop

95
00:04:02.368 --> 00:04:03.685
that before it even happened?

96
00:04:03.685 --> 00:04:08.653
>> And that's just a feature of this,
and it's the best product for

97
00:04:08.653 --> 00:04:10.379
malware in the world.

98
00:04:10.379 --> 00:04:13.049
So viruses and
trojans certainly might be a problem.

99
00:04:13.049 --> 00:04:15.370
But they're nothing compared
to what malware can give us.

100
00:04:15.370 --> 00:04:17.490
And malware comes in very small packages.

101
00:04:17.490 --> 00:04:19.080
And, so, I mean, they can be on apps.

102
00:04:19.080 --> 00:04:19.820
They're very, very small.

103
00:04:19.820 --> 00:04:22.403
I've seen some really small ones
that I was looking at the other day.

104
00:04:22.403 --> 00:04:25.979
But nonetheless, so we can come here and
we can see malware.

105
00:04:25.979 --> 00:04:30.335
Let me go right to a screen
that shows some malware.

106
00:04:30.335 --> 00:04:32.124
Where did I put it?
Right here.

107
00:04:32.124 --> 00:04:33.447
And this is showing on this demo.

108
00:04:33.447 --> 00:04:36.466
[LAUGH] And, again, if your work looks
like this you guys got a problem.

109
00:04:36.466 --> 00:04:41.920
But nonetheless, I can come in here and
say here's my malware.

110
00:04:41.920 --> 00:04:45.670
And again we're determining the file
disposition through this product

111
00:04:45.670 --> 00:04:47.580
by sending something called an AMP cloud,

112
00:04:47.580 --> 00:04:49.230
Advanced Malware Protection
cloud at CISCO.

113
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:52.152
And they basically gave us a file
disposition and they came back and

114
00:04:52.152 --> 00:04:52.731
said, hey.

115
00:04:52.731 --> 00:04:53.939
This is bad, right.

116
00:04:53.939 --> 00:04:57.120
And they're telling us this file
came back with a high fret score.

117
00:04:57.120 --> 00:05:00.153
So go ahead and click on this,
and now when we see this file and

118
00:05:00.153 --> 00:05:03.319
what this product will give us
is what's called a trajectory.

119
00:05:03.319 --> 00:05:06.431
In other words when it got into
your network, where did it go?

120
00:05:06.431 --> 00:05:07.894
So I mean,
this is just one of the features.

121
00:05:07.894 --> 00:05:12.453
I'm just scratching the surface on what
we're gonna cover in our episodes.

122
00:05:12.453 --> 00:05:16.842
And this is gonna show me where it's gone,
who it talked to.

123
00:05:16.842 --> 00:05:22.670
And the things it gives me is I'm
not gonna go through that right now.

124
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:24.025
But I'll do this in the episodes.

125
00:05:24.025 --> 00:05:27.313
And the fact is,
we'll look at the thread score and

126
00:05:27.313 --> 00:05:31.321
the report on it that came from
what's called Talos sandbox.

127
00:05:31.321 --> 00:05:33.390
Nonetheless, I can also download the file,
right.

128
00:05:33.390 --> 00:05:36.423
So we can use it in our own sandbox and
so on, and stuff like that.

129
00:05:36.423 --> 00:05:38.813
But let's go back here to
give more of a big picture.

130
00:05:38.813 --> 00:05:42.400
But the idea was this,
malware's a serious issue.

131
00:05:42.400 --> 00:05:45.100
This is a very serious product.

132
00:05:45.100 --> 00:05:47.430
And can other companies do a lot of this?

133
00:05:47.430 --> 00:05:48.680
The other companies can.

134
00:05:48.680 --> 00:05:53.304
And, again, I'm not gonna pick on other
companies like, you got Palo Alto and

135
00:05:53.304 --> 00:05:56.766
McAfee and a lot of people use
these in their fine products.

136
00:05:56.766 --> 00:05:59.807
That's not what makes
this one sing above them.

137
00:05:59.807 --> 00:06:03.462
What makes them, this product sing
above your other products and

138
00:06:03.462 --> 00:06:06.461
I'll pick on Palo Alto in this case,
poor Palo Alto.

139
00:06:06.461 --> 00:06:08.643
Because I go out to a lot
of companies that are like.

140
00:06:08.643 --> 00:06:10.153
Why should I buy this over Palo Alto?

141
00:06:10.153 --> 00:06:12.340
Cuz that's what about we're about to buy.

142
00:06:12.340 --> 00:06:16.134
And I'll show them why, because you've
got like at least nine administrative

143
00:06:16.134 --> 00:06:19.543
interfaces with Palo Alto doing
the same thing that we're doing here.

144
00:06:19.543 --> 00:06:20.913
And it can't do it quite as well.

145
00:06:20.913 --> 00:06:24.117
Not only that, you don't have
any correlation between events.

146
00:06:24.117 --> 00:06:26.253
So now we have this single interface.

147
00:06:26.253 --> 00:06:31.447
This phenomenal, intuitive GUI that
can help us use our Snort rules to

148
00:06:31.447 --> 00:06:38.540

149
00:06:38.540 --> 00:06:41.220
All on one screen,
with correlation between events.

150
00:06:41.220 --> 00:06:41.940
You got SEM reporting.

151
00:06:41.940 --> 00:06:43.588
That's a pretty big deal.

152
00:06:43.588 --> 00:06:47.359
So we've got all this stuff that can
occur with this one piece of management.

153
00:06:47.359 --> 00:06:50.687
And so again,
if you're looking at other products say.

154
00:06:50.687 --> 00:06:53.592
Hey, I wanna see one administrative
interface for all of these.

155
00:06:53.592 --> 00:06:55.079
I don't want this siloed approach.

156
00:06:55.079 --> 00:06:59.365
Where I have, appliance, appliance,
appliance, appliance, VPN con triggers,

157
00:06:59.365 --> 00:07:00.923
router switches and all this.

158
00:07:00.923 --> 00:07:02.964
In this case we've got our ASA.

159
00:07:02.964 --> 00:07:05.053
You, you can have an appliance as well.

160
00:07:05.053 --> 00:07:10.394
But the ASA is a phenomenal
product to run this on.

161
00:07:10.394 --> 00:07:14.088
What it does is it gives us our routing,
switching, VPN, and

162
00:07:14.088 --> 00:07:17.780
all that other stuff that we
all know that an ASA does.

163
00:07:17.780 --> 00:07:21.146
But now we have the power, or
what we call FirePOWER, right.

164
00:07:21.146 --> 00:07:24.503
So FirePOWER, the term is very
important to understand here, Don.

165
00:07:24.503 --> 00:07:26.406
Because, it's used a couple
of different ways.

166
00:07:26.406 --> 00:07:30.798
This was created by Sourcefire before
Cisco bought them and FirePOWER came up.

167
00:07:30.798 --> 00:07:34.714
And it really defines the power
of the next generation IPS,

168
00:07:34.714 --> 00:07:36.602
next generation firewall.

169
00:07:36.602 --> 00:07:38.878
>> And it just sounds cool
as a marketing term, right?

170
00:07:38.878 --> 00:07:39.481
>> It does.

171
00:07:39.481 --> 00:07:41.896
And so, I don't show it here.

172
00:07:41.896 --> 00:07:46.411
But what the FirePOWER,
where the power is all capitalized.

173
00:07:46.411 --> 00:07:47.386
I think you're gonna see that going away.

174
00:07:47.386 --> 00:07:48.756
So now that Cisco's got it.

175
00:07:48.756 --> 00:07:51.341
When you run an ASA with this product

176
00:07:51.341 --> 00:07:55.927
on it the actual term they call
it is FirePOWER module, right?

177
00:07:55.927 --> 00:07:56.937
Is that the case?
I don't know.

178
00:07:56.937 --> 00:07:58.586
I guess.

179
00:07:58.586 --> 00:08:01.267
It's really hard for
me to define all these terms.

180
00:08:01.267 --> 00:08:02.217
They seem to change a lot.

181
00:08:02.217 --> 00:08:03.890
As I was writing the book,
I just kinda gave up.

182
00:08:03.890 --> 00:08:07.474
And says, I'm gonna call the FireSIGHT
Management Center, the Defense Center and

183
00:08:07.474 --> 00:08:08.644
just kind of stick with it.

184
00:08:08.644 --> 00:08:11.569
But there's also another
term called FireSIGHT.

185
00:08:11.569 --> 00:08:13.706
This is a very powerful technology.

186
00:08:13.706 --> 00:08:16.906
So we see things like FirePOWER,
FireSIGHT and

187
00:08:16.906 --> 00:08:22.349
they had a technological definition and
now they're kind of a lot of marketing.

188
00:08:22.349 --> 00:08:23.902
So, you actually probably saw,

189
00:08:23.902 --> 00:08:26.738
it said FirePOWER with FireSIGHT
administration, right?

190
00:08:26.738 --> 00:08:27.736
What does that mean?

191
00:08:27.736 --> 00:08:32.093
The FirePOWER again is our power
of the next generation IPS.

192
00:08:32.093 --> 00:08:37.661
And the FireSIGHT is actually a passive
technology that scans our networks and

193
00:08:37.661 --> 00:08:42.228
gathers information about user's hosts and
in applications.

194
00:08:42.228 --> 00:08:43.900
It's a very powerful tool.

195
00:08:43.900 --> 00:08:45.316
I love FireSIGHT.

196
00:08:45.316 --> 00:08:47.731
And so we will go in that in
depth into these series, right?

197
00:08:47.731 --> 00:08:50.448
Into FireSIGHT and
into how FirePOWER works and all that.

198
00:08:50.448 --> 00:08:51.771
Let's take a little bit more.

199
00:08:51.771 --> 00:08:53.722
We won't spend a lot more
time in taking your time.

200
00:08:53.722 --> 00:08:57.112
But I want you guys to understand how
great this product actually is, and

201
00:08:57.112 --> 00:08:58.846
what it can do for your corporation.

202
00:08:58.846 --> 00:09:00.332
And now there's yet another term.

203
00:09:00.332 --> 00:09:03.180
So we've got, well Sourcefire, right?

204
00:09:03.180 --> 00:09:04.883
And that term is pretty much going away.

205
00:09:04.883 --> 00:09:06.601
We see it still a lot.

206
00:09:06.601 --> 00:09:08.923
But it's gonna be just Cisco, right?

207
00:09:08.923 --> 00:09:10.997
And then we've got FirePOWER.

208
00:09:10.997 --> 00:09:13.895
And that's the power again,
as I mentioned of the next generation IPS,

209
00:09:13.895 --> 00:09:15.045
next generation firewall.

210
00:09:15.045 --> 00:09:17.390
It runs on our managed devices and
our defense.

211
00:09:17.390 --> 00:09:20.630
Remember our managed devices
are in ASA with FirePOWER.

212
00:09:20.630 --> 00:09:23.603
They're already an appliance
that's running this.

213
00:09:23.603 --> 00:09:27.169
And then we get all our vents and
correlation back at the defense center,

214
00:09:27.169 --> 00:09:28.759
FireSIGHT management center.

215
00:09:28.759 --> 00:09:29.897
The newbie I showed you.

216
00:09:29.897 --> 00:09:31.963
There's another term called FireSIGHT.

217
00:09:31.963 --> 00:09:36.564
And, what this is, is a passive
technology that runs in the background.

218
00:09:36.564 --> 00:09:39.760
Gathering information on host users and
applications.

219
00:09:39.760 --> 00:09:41.320
And it connects to our eld app.

220
00:09:41.320 --> 00:09:45.260
And so now we can, so basically we can
put a name and a user to an IP address or

221
00:09:45.260 --> 00:09:45.830
something like that.

222
00:09:45.830 --> 00:09:47.990
Very cool, powerful technology and

223
00:09:47.990 --> 00:09:52.990
we'll spend a lot of time on that
when we go through the episodes.

224
00:09:52.990 --> 00:09:55.300
Let me say there's yet
another term, right?

225
00:09:55.300 --> 00:09:57.570
FireAMP and who knows where
these terms are gonna end up.

226
00:09:57.570 --> 00:09:59.760
But the fact is FireAMP
advanced mail protection.

227
00:09:59.760 --> 00:10:00.440
There's two types.

There's a network based and a host based.

And we'll talk about that

230
00:10:05.760 --> 00:10:07.480
Malware is a big piece of this.

231
00:10:07.480 --> 00:10:10.040
Right.
And it is a separate license.

232
00:10:10.040 --> 00:10:10.950
Right.
Everything's separate.

233
00:10:10.950 --> 00:10:12.297
Cisco figured out this.

00:10:12.297 --> 00:10:15.791
Hey, we're not gonna just buy this product

00:10:15.791 --> 00:10:17.556

So now let's just go back and take a look

00:10:39.690 --> 00:10:43.400

I have my whitelist, I have my blacklist.

This was the first known

00:10:59.528 --> 00:11:02.593

zero day attack occurred.

And these indication of compromise

So we kind of bench marked these hosts and

00:11:09.507 --> 00:11:11.030

00:11:12.330 --> 00:11:16.180

00:11:16.180 --> 00:11:18.706

00:11:18.706 --> 00:11:23.447

00:11:23.447 --> 00:11:25.043

00:11:25.043 --> 00:11:28.061

And if you need more throughput,

So, if you find yourself

you're working for a company,

Small business you could

That's really branch office kind

>> Yeah, maybe at 5512 or 5515 or 25 or

something like that,
again I was just Make it an analogy.

That, hey you can go all the way down.

Yeah, so just add an extra

>> And you can have that too.

Now if that sounds exciting to you,

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd introduces the viewers to Cisco FirePOWER (formerly SourceFIRE). He describes the primary components of a FirePOWER deployment and briefly demonstrates FirePOWER, the FireSIGHT Management Center and FireAMP.
episodes.title: Introduction to FirePOWER

I am so busy, I'm getting called by

Sourcefire a couple of years ago now,

51
00:02:31.211 --> 00:02:31.757
Right?

So, the thing is there ae some different

Right?
The 5500 X series,

can take the new software module for
the lower end of 5500s, and for

00:02:47.699 --> 00:02:50.870

And so depending on
the performance that you need,

really depends how many zeros

And these terms were created by

So what does that mean?

Well, the next generation firewall is

00:03:47.309 --> 00:03:51.575

just look at all the data, watch it come

It does take some of our throughput,

00:04:01.011 --> 00:04:06.016
we're getting truly in inspect the data,

So, the firePOWER is the power

00:04:10.660 --> 00:04:11.275
Right?

83

FireSIGHT is a very powerful technology.

00:04:13.574 --> 00:04:14.201
I love it.

85

We'll go through this.

It's a passive, not an active,

Users, databases, applications,

00:04:28.048 --> 00:04:32.666

00:04:32.666 --> 00:04:38.235

00:04:42.758 --> 00:04:46.205
we can add third party

And so for example, a lot of people

00:04:50.125 --> 00:04:52.203

96
00:04:52.203 --> 00:04:55.362
Now with fireSIGHT technologies we
can also have active scanning and

97
00:04:55.362 --> 00:04:56.455

98
00:04:56.455 --> 00:05:01.459
And then the last thing here is fireAMP,

99
00:05:01.459 --> 00:05:04.964
And this is the key to
really a high success here.

100
00:05:04.964 --> 00:05:07.763
You've got the power of
the next generation IPS.

101
00:05:07.763 --> 00:05:10.355
You've got FireSIGHT database technology,

102
00:05:10.355 --> 00:05:15.216

103
00:05:15.216 --> 00:05:16.749
So is that important?

104
00:05:16.749 --> 00:05:20.593
It's the most important piece because
what's our biggest threat today is

00:05:20.593 --> 00:05:23.227

it's Malware.

106
00:05:23.227 --> 00:05:24.877
Right?
That's how we get things like

107
00:05:24.877 --> 00:05:25.631
say Ransomware.

108
00:05:25.631 --> 00:05:30.086
Network comes in very small sizes,
or somewhat medium sizes, but

109
00:05:30.086 --> 00:05:35.347
we can get them in apps, very small, but
malware is our biggest threat today.

110
00:05:35.347 --> 00:05:38.959
And so this helps us take care

111
00:05:38.959 --> 00:05:41.135
And again we'll talk about
Ransomware later, but

112
00:05:41.135 --> 00:05:42.963
then that's a piece of Malware isn't it?

113

>> Now, in the slide here we can see

00:05:46.659 --> 00:05:50.765
pretty much all the exposure I have

00:05:50.765 --> 00:05:53.224
Has Cisco expanded to any of
the other product lines, or

00:05:53.224 --> 00:05:54.804
is it all within the ASAs right now?

117
00:05:54.804 --> 00:05:56.581
>> That's a really good question.

118
00:05:56.581 --> 00:05:59.629
I haven't seen anything yet,
but I've heard a lot, and

119
00:05:59.629 --> 00:06:04.205
actually I've searched on their website,
because I had heard of some firePOWER, so

00:06:04.205 --> 00:06:06.970
let me come back to these

121
00:06:06.970 --> 00:06:08.410
So the, the terms firePOWER,

122
00:06:08.410 --> 00:06:11.430
fireSIGHT, fireAMP, I gave you their

00:06:11.430 --> 00:06:14.612

00:06:14.612 --> 00:06:17.583
However, Cisco now doesn't

00:06:17.583 --> 00:06:20.976
I'll use the word sourcefire a lot,
and it's in my book a lot, and

00:06:20.976 --> 00:06:23.785
I use some of the other,
what we'll call older terms.

127
00:06:23.785 --> 00:06:26.923
But firePOWER now is,
is what Cisco's going to,

128
00:06:26.923 --> 00:06:30.450
the term is just this technology
in a whole, in a group.

129
00:06:30.450 --> 00:06:32.679
So firePOWER is gonna have

00:06:32.679 --> 00:06:35.444
It gets kinda hard,

00:06:35.444 --> 00:06:38.579

00:06:38.579 --> 00:06:39.961
I'm like, well, what do I call this now?

00:06:39.961 --> 00:06:42.979
And so I kinda make the decision,

But the fact is you gotta kinda

00:06:48.118 --> 00:06:50.764

00:06:50.764 --> 00:06:54.680

138
00:06:54.680 --> 00:06:56.690

00:35:15.880 --> 00:35:20.760

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd demonstrates how to activate FirePOWER on a Cisco ASA that shipped with the FirePOWER module pre-installed. He also demonstrates how to upgrade a pre-existing ASA to support FirePOWER. He also describes the Cisco FirePOWER licensing model.

episodes.description: This episode begins the configuration process for enabling Cisco FirePOWER on an ASA or dedicated FirePOWER appliance. Todd explains how FirePOWER uses System Policies and Health Policies to control managed devices. He also describes some of the limitations of the FireSIGHT Management Center in larger environments.
episodes.title: System and Health Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd explains how the FireSIGHT FMC handles malware. He also demonstrates how you can create custom File Policies which can restrict data under any number of circumstances.
episodes.title: File Policies

episodes.description: Intrusion Prevention System policies are the backbone of Cisco FirePOWER. This episode demonstrates how to implement IPS policies and their components. Todd also explains the various layers of an IPS policy, how to tune the policy and adjusting rule states.

Whatever.

916

I'm not saying, hey follow this along-

Because now I can push this out, and

And, typically, again, I would not have

Cuz I want to see what's

Once I see what happens and I tune it

As a matter of fact, most people come

Security Over Connectivity or

A lot of times though for me.

I'm always telling people

1006

>> [LAUGH]
>> Right?

And up and running and tying it all

episodes.description: This two part episode covers Access Control Policies, which are a critical piece of a FirePOWER deployment. This video covers Security Intelligence, HTTP response pages, URL filtering and tying in IPS and file policies.
episodes.title: Access Control Policies

I might just turn them off so
I can come in here and say, you know what?

525
00:22:58.430 --> 00:23:00.630
Man, I've got so
much data I'm trying to get through,

526
00:23:00.630 --> 00:23:02.180
this thing's just slowing me down.

527
00:23:02.180 --> 00:23:04.990
So I'm going to come down here and
say intrusion policy, and

528
00:23:04.990 --> 00:23:06.400
I'm going to say no rules active.

529
00:23:06.400 --> 00:23:09.400
In other words I'm just saying go
straight to security intelligence.

530
00:23:09.400 --> 00:23:12.870
This might not be a bad thing my friends,
it depends on your network.

531
00:23:12.870 --> 00:23:15.731
>> And if you do that, if you're just
going through security intelligence, well,

532
00:23:15.731 --> 00:23:17.601
you're downloading that information for.

533
00:23:17.601 --> 00:23:21.338
So it's kinda like following their best
practice, but if you have exceptions.

534
00:23:21.338 --> 00:23:22.384
>> Yeah.

535
00:23:22.384 --> 00:23:23.893
>> It kind takes that power away from you,
right?

536
00:23:23.893 --> 00:23:26.220
>> Yeah.
And the one thing, when I saw this,

537
00:23:26.220 --> 00:23:29.193
I was like, okay,
this seems like a little overkill.

538
00:23:29.193 --> 00:23:33.173
It's a lot of work, that's what my access
control policy is for, I'm supposed to go

539
00:23:33.173 --> 00:23:37.127
through here, but remember, I can't say
enough about how smart these people are.

540
00:23:37.127 --> 00:23:39.101
There is a reason that they did this,
right?

541
00:23:39.101 --> 00:23:43.238
We're spending a lot of time going through
the access control policy and the key was,

542
00:23:43.238 --> 00:23:44.790
remember I told you yesterday,

543
00:23:44.790 --> 00:23:48.850
as we're determining the file type if we
have a file policy, what are we doing?

544
00:23:48.850 --> 00:23:50.140
We're transferring that file.

545
00:23:50.140 --> 00:23:51.890
And if we don't get an answer
by the time we get to the end,

546
00:23:51.890 --> 00:23:53.290
we're gonna send that file.

547
00:23:53.290 --> 00:23:55.976
So we're going to,
this is why they set this up.

548
00:23:55.976 --> 00:23:59.443
While determining the file type for
example, let's go through the sort rules

549
00:23:59.443 --> 00:24:02.504
and that's what this is saying and
that's why they did this, okay?

550
00:24:02.504 --> 00:24:04.642
So again, you might not need that,

551
00:24:04.642 --> 00:24:07.650
you might not wanna change
the network analysis.

552
00:24:07.650 --> 00:24:09.960
You'll determine that when we get
to the preprocessor settings.

553
00:24:09.960 --> 00:24:12.730
All right, so this looks pretty good,
but we really haven't done a lot yet.

554
00:24:12.730 --> 00:24:15.370
I keep saying that, we've been saying
that for two days now but, woo,

555
00:24:15.370 --> 00:24:18.585
we're getting to that point where we're
actually gonna do something right now.

556
00:24:18.585 --> 00:24:20.621
So I'm gonna come back here and
create some rules.

557
00:24:20.621 --> 00:24:24.871
Now I can leave this alone and just do
security intelligence, log my thing, but

558
00:24:24.871 --> 00:24:28.805
I'm going through security intelligence
and if it's not blacklisted,

559
00:24:28.805 --> 00:24:32.563
which means it's gonna be dropped,
I'm just gonna drop it anyways.

560
00:24:32.563 --> 00:24:35.255
That's what this rule says so far.

561
00:24:35.255 --> 00:24:35.975
I might be good with that.

episodes.description: This two part episode covers Access Control Policies, which are a critical piece of a FirePOWER deployment. This video covers applying an Access Control Policy to your managed devices, collecting event data, and analyzing event data once the policy is in place.
episodes.title: Access Control Policies Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.190 --> 00:00:15.211
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:15.211 --> 00:00:17.231
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.231 --> 00:00:22.711
I'm your host, Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of Cisco Firepower.

5
00:00:22.711 --> 00:00:26.408
And in this episode, we're going to
be doing the exciting conclusion to

6
00:00:26.408 --> 00:00:28.601
the cliffhanger finale we had in part one.

7
00:00:28.601 --> 00:00:31.075
Where we got a chance to see
our Access Control policy and

8
00:00:31.075 --> 00:00:33.301
some of the rules that we
could put in place there.

9
00:00:33.301 --> 00:00:36.370
Now we're gonna look at some
of the advanced features.

10
00:00:36.370 --> 00:00:39.208
There's a ton of stuff that Todd wanted
to get to in the last episode that we're

11
00:00:39.208 --> 00:00:40.160
gonna take a look at here.

12
00:00:40.160 --> 00:00:43.708
Because when you start customizing these
policies for your own environment,

13
00:00:43.708 --> 00:00:47.091
you're gonna need a lot of these features
to get things set just the way your

14
00:00:47.091 --> 00:00:47.965
company needs it.

15
00:00:47.965 --> 00:00:52.210
So without further ado, I'm gonna turn
it over to the big man, Mr. Todd Lammle.

16
00:00:52.210 --> 00:00:53.670
Todd, where do we go from here?

17
00:00:53.670 --> 00:00:59.400
>> I'm gonna show you some complex Access
Control policies, if we have time, [LAUGH]

18
00:00:59.400 --> 00:01:04.740
to go through and take a look at what
some experts have done, other experts.

19
00:01:04.740 --> 00:01:06.870
All right, so let's add another rule here.

20
00:01:06.870 --> 00:01:10.220
And this one's gonna be
Monitor All Traffic.

21
00:01:10.220 --> 00:01:14.826
And so I'm gonna allow rule,
I'm just gonna say it's a Monitor rule.

22
00:01:14.826 --> 00:01:18.639
Basically I'm gonna say, hey when
something comes in, alert me, log it and

23
00:01:18.639 --> 00:01:21.235
notice right away,
logging is enabled by default.

24
00:01:21.235 --> 00:01:25.350
Cuz all I'm saying if anything comes
in here, if it hits this line.

25
00:01:25.350 --> 00:01:28.330
Log can send it and it connects you
in advance, and I'm gonna see it.

26
00:01:28.330 --> 00:01:30.520
All right, and
notice logging is enabled by default.

27
00:01:30.520 --> 00:01:34.780
And that's the only thing,
I'm not choosing anything else,

28
00:01:34.780 --> 00:01:35.900
logging into connections.

29
00:01:37.420 --> 00:01:41.460
Now, I also want to say something like,
I want to trust some traffic.

30
00:01:41.460 --> 00:01:44.520
That doesn't mean it's not gonna
be blocked later down when

31
00:01:44.520 --> 00:01:47.470
it gets to the bottom,
cuz it certainly will.

32
00:01:47.470 --> 00:01:50.040
The trust means you're not
gonna go to the next rule.

33
00:01:50.040 --> 00:01:52.430
I'm gonna come back here to Add Rule.

34
00:01:52.430 --> 00:01:55.460
And I'm gonna say, Trust UDP DNS.

35
00:01:55.460 --> 00:01:59.920
And this one I do a lot because really,
I don't want to see this.

36
00:01:59.920 --> 00:02:03.160
What is the biggest traffic that
I see in a lot of my networks?

37
00:02:03.160 --> 00:02:05.797
Users are using DNS over UDP right?

38
00:02:05.797 --> 00:02:06.854
Cuz that's our queries.

39
00:02:06.854 --> 00:02:09.133
We see that all the time I'm like,
those are fine,

40
00:02:09.133 --> 00:02:10.790
I'm not really worried about them.

41
00:02:10.790 --> 00:02:14.225
Honestly, I don't even want to see
the connection because I'm getting enough

42
00:02:14.225 --> 00:02:14.950
events as it is.

43
00:02:14.950 --> 00:02:15.579
So, this one I use.

44
00:02:15.579 --> 00:02:18.485
And so I'm gonna trust this,
that means as soon as I see this traffic,

45
00:02:18.485 --> 00:02:21.558
boom go to [INAUDIBLE], you're fine,
you're not gonna hit the last one.

46
00:02:21.558 --> 00:02:22.930
All right, so we're gonna trust that.

47
00:02:22.930 --> 00:02:24.220
So now I have to set this up.

48
00:02:24.220 --> 00:02:28.718
And so I'm gonna say leave the networks,
I don't even really care, and

49
00:02:28.718 --> 00:02:31.910
I'm gonna come to the applications,
I'm sorry.

50
00:02:31.910 --> 00:02:35.460
We wanna go to ports in this case here.

51
00:02:35.460 --> 00:02:39.310
And I wanna say, if it's DNS over UDP,
Add to Destination.

52
00:02:39.310 --> 00:02:41.890
And we're gonna go ahead log it.

53
00:02:41.890 --> 00:02:45.690
So, we're gonna trust DNS over UDP,
very simple rule.

54
00:02:45.690 --> 00:02:50.170
[COUGH] And, now at this point,
I can log it or not log it.

55
00:02:50.170 --> 00:02:53.610
Maybe I don't want this logged,
I just want this to trust some traffic.

56
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:55.530
So I'm probably not gonna log this.

57
00:02:55.530 --> 00:02:57.750
Remember I have that monitor all.

58
00:02:57.750 --> 00:02:59.440
So if we look at our rules right here,

59
00:02:59.440 --> 00:03:01.738
we can see that we're
blocking [INAUDIBLE] cells.

60
00:03:01.738 --> 00:03:05.890
We're logging it, we're monitoring all
other traffic and this one's not seen it.

61
00:03:05.890 --> 00:03:08.350
But wait,
this kinda doesn't make any sense.

62
00:03:08.350 --> 00:03:11.140
I don't want this log,
don't even want to see the traffic.

63
00:03:11.140 --> 00:03:12.510
But the line above it says monitor.

64
00:03:12.510 --> 00:03:15.311
So what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna take this rule, and

65
00:03:15.311 --> 00:03:17.130
I'll move this up here to the top.

66
00:03:17.130 --> 00:03:20.090
And now, when that comes through,
I'm gonna trust and send to the egress.

67
00:03:20.090 --> 00:03:23.610
And it's not even gonna go
down to the next line, right?

68
00:03:23.610 --> 00:03:27.631
Then the other thing is, is if it's
blocked here, then I won't monitor it.

69
00:03:27.631 --> 00:03:30.673
I won't see it, I won't get a connection,
I will see the lock, and that's fine.

70
00:03:30.673 --> 00:03:32.400
And maybe we just want
to leave it like this.

71
00:03:32.400 --> 00:03:33.518
But I'm gonna move the monitor right here.

72
00:03:33.518 --> 00:03:36.458
So I'm gonna trust this data,
not log it in any way.

73
00:03:36.458 --> 00:03:39.889
And then I'm gonna log everything
else that comes in, and

74
00:03:39.889 --> 00:03:41.860
I'm not gonna do anything to it.

75
00:03:41.860 --> 00:03:45.780
But just log it at this point, all right?

76
00:03:45.780 --> 00:03:49.433
So now let's go ahead and do another for
fun, cuz this is fun, right?

77
00:03:49.433 --> 00:03:49.933
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

78
00:03:49.933 --> 00:03:51.438
>> This is where people start,

79
00:03:51.438 --> 00:03:53.257
they see you creating the rules and

80
00:03:53.257 --> 00:03:56.079
in our minds, we're thinking, okay.
What rules

81
00:03:56.079 --> 00:03:58.762
would I be making for my environment?
What's

82
00:03:58.762 --> 00:04:01.350
the kind of stuff that we'd put in place?
So here's where we really start

83
00:04:01.350 --> 00:04:04.570
customizing it, and thinking of
all the power that's out there.

84
00:04:04.570 --> 00:04:05.337
It's really the best part.

85
00:04:05.337 --> 00:04:06.290
>> It is the best part.

86
00:04:06.290 --> 00:04:09.612
And now we're gonna get to
the meat of the subject,

87
00:04:09.612 --> 00:04:13.760
because remember we created that
file policy and IPS policy?

88
00:04:13.760 --> 00:04:15.684
And how do we put those into
our Access Control policy?

89
00:04:15.684 --> 00:04:18.957
I take an allow rule,
can't do it with any other rule.

90
00:04:18.957 --> 00:04:23.424
I create an allow rule, and
I'm just gonna name it Attach IPS and

91
00:04:23.424 --> 00:04:25.260
File Policy, all right?

92
00:04:25.260 --> 00:04:29.800
Now I can create a rule for each one, it
doesn't make any difference in this case.

93
00:04:29.800 --> 00:04:32.760
I kinda put them together, it's kinda fun.

94
00:04:32.760 --> 00:04:36.500
So I'm gonna say allow, and
I'm not gonna do anything here.

95
00:04:36.500 --> 00:04:37.570
I'm not gonna change anything.

96
00:04:37.570 --> 00:04:40.580
I am gonna come back to this
geo-location issue though.

97
00:04:40.580 --> 00:04:43.470
Okay, Inspection, so
I'm gonna come to Inspection.

98
00:04:43.470 --> 00:04:48.450
I'm gonna say if my intrusion policy for
this role is, there it is right there.

99
00:04:48.450 --> 00:04:49.470
There's the IPS policy we created.

100
00:04:49.470 --> 00:04:55.910
And my file policy for this rule,
there it is right there.

101
00:04:55.910 --> 00:04:57.425
So, now, I'm attaching this
notice it's an allow rule.

102
00:04:57.425 --> 00:05:02.290
But you've seen the allow rule, that
doesn't mean the traffic's allowed, right?

103
00:05:02.290 --> 00:05:04.971
It has to go through my file policy and
has to go through my IPS policy,

104
00:05:04.971 --> 00:05:06.230

105
00:05:06.230 --> 00:05:10.520
So if that's the case,
I need to make sure that we log, right?

106
00:05:10.520 --> 00:05:14.473
Because if this happens and gets dropped
by my IPS policy or my file policy,

107
00:05:14.473 --> 00:05:18.260
I'm not gonna know it if I don't log it,
and that would be ridiculous.

108
00:05:18.260 --> 00:05:20.302
So do I log at the beginning,
log at the end?

109
00:05:20.302 --> 00:05:22.450
It depends how many
connection events you get.

110
00:05:22.450 --> 00:05:24.337
So let me just tell you so
I've called Cisco at times said,

111
00:05:24.337 --> 00:05:26.310
hey I am having this problem,
this problem, this problem.

112
00:05:26.310 --> 00:05:29.438
They're like, okay let's change all your
rules to log at the beginning of the end,

113
00:05:29.438 --> 00:05:30.860
so we can really see what's going on.

114
00:05:30.860 --> 00:05:34.580
So really the question comes down to,
are you having some problems?

115
00:05:34.580 --> 00:05:37.310
Do you really need to see what's going on
or you just want to hear about it when

116
00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:39.250
it's been dropped,
maybe we just log at the beginning.

117
00:05:39.250 --> 00:05:41.670
In this case here,
I wanna log at the beginning and

118
00:05:41.670 --> 00:05:44.790
the end because I like to get
events in this environment, right?

119
00:05:44.790 --> 00:05:47.092
>> I guess if we wanted to
customize that separately for

120
00:05:47.092 --> 00:05:50.598
the intrusion prevention versus the file
policy, then that would be an example

121
00:05:50.598 --> 00:05:53.345
where we might split those into
two rules instead of one rule?

122
00:05:53.345 --> 00:05:59.647
>> You could split them into separate
rules just for administratively, I guess.

123
00:05:59.647 --> 00:06:00.956
>> Okay.

124
00:06:00.956 --> 00:06:04.279
>> Also, depending on maybe where
you want them in your list,

125
00:06:04.279 --> 00:06:06.080
if you think about it like that.

126
00:06:06.080 --> 00:06:09.210
So maybe I want one at the top,
and if it gets all the way down.

127
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:10.360
Then it hits this IPS
policy type of thing.

128
00:06:10.360 --> 00:06:12.695
So when you think about it-
>> Then you'd wanna [CROSSTALK].

129
00:06:12.695 --> 00:06:14.066
>> So many scenarios, right?

130
00:06:14.066 --> 00:06:18.607
It's kinda like when you create
Access Control lists on a router or a ASA.

131
00:06:18.607 --> 00:06:21.601
Man you really have to think about it,
and this is no different.

132
00:06:21.601 --> 00:06:23.080
How are we gonna see traffic?

133
00:06:23.080 --> 00:06:24.430
How does it go through?

134
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:26.500
It gets a little convoluted here.

135
00:06:26.500 --> 00:06:31.150
Let's do one more thing,
and then we'll apply this.

136
00:06:31.150 --> 00:06:34.715
And while we're applying, I'm gonna look
at some advanced Access Control policies.

137
00:06:34.715 --> 00:06:38.219
Where we're using administrator rules,
standard rules and again, the reason you

138
00:06:38.219 --> 00:06:41.521
would do that is just administratively to
break things up to make them easier for

139
00:06:41.521 --> 00:06:42.080
you to read.

140
00:06:42.080 --> 00:06:44.014
All right, and
I can create new categories as well.

141
00:06:44.014 --> 00:06:48.142
So we have another rule and I can sit
here and say, hey I'm gonna put this,

142
00:06:48.142 --> 00:06:51.020
this new rule is going to be,
I'll block Germany.

143
00:06:51.020 --> 00:06:53.275
Now, I don't have anything
against Germany, but

144
00:06:53.275 --> 00:06:55.590
you're gonna see this in
my Access Control policy.

145
00:06:55.590 --> 00:06:58.210
And the reason why is,
I found some malware out there.

146
00:06:58.210 --> 00:07:00.330
And it's fun to go out there and
see it get blocked.

147
00:07:00.330 --> 00:07:05.160
So we go to Germany, we get that blocked,
and it shows up in our connection events,

148
00:07:05.160 --> 00:07:06.380
it's awesome.

149
00:07:06.380 --> 00:07:09.220
So at this point here,
I can say where do I put this rule?

150
00:07:09.220 --> 00:07:13.221
I want to put it into Category, Standard
Rules, Administrative Rules, Root Rules.

151
00:07:13.221 --> 00:07:14.885
In this case, it's not important to us.

152
00:07:14.885 --> 00:07:16.463
We don't have a big Access Control policy.

153
00:07:16.463 --> 00:07:18.200
I'm just gonna put
everything in the Standard.

154
00:07:18.200 --> 00:07:20.010
I can say, where do I put this?

155
00:07:20.010 --> 00:07:24.020
Below, above, below rule four, below rule.

156
00:07:24.020 --> 00:07:25.150
I'll just put it,
I'll just say below rule [INAUDIBLE].

157
00:07:25.150 --> 00:07:29.360
Now, remember I can just drag and drop it
as well, and that's typically what I do.

158
00:07:29.360 --> 00:07:31.589
But if you have a really
long Access Control policy,

159
00:07:31.589 --> 00:07:33.220
which I'm gonna show you in a second.

160
00:07:33.220 --> 00:07:38.352
Then you might want to consider
doing this and keeping this in mind.

161
00:07:38.352 --> 00:07:40.848
Now in this case here,
let's go over here to Networks and

162
00:07:40.848 --> 00:07:42.150
I'm seeing a Block Germany.

163
00:07:42.150 --> 00:07:45.915
So I'm gonna just block with reset,
and I'm gonna do a network here, and

164
00:07:45.915 --> 00:07:47.820
I'm gonna click on Geo-location.

165
00:07:47.820 --> 00:07:52.354
And I want to find Germany, and I can look
through here, and I'm sure in Europe and

166
00:07:52.354 --> 00:07:53.090
somewhere.

167
00:07:53.090 --> 00:07:56.712
But notice this, I'm gonna type in
Germany and there it is right there.

168
00:07:56.712 --> 00:08:01.065
And it's actually the DEU right, so
we're gonna see that if my source.

169
00:08:01.065 --> 00:08:03.411
Is DEU is really what it is.

170
00:08:03.411 --> 00:08:04.850
Germany.

171
00:08:04.850 --> 00:08:06.290
Here I have Deutschland right.

172
00:08:06.290 --> 00:08:07.942
The homeland or whatever.

173
00:08:07.942 --> 00:08:11.080
Anyways and
then we're going to block with reset.

174
00:08:11.080 --> 00:08:13.386
And once the other so
I'm making it pretty simple.

175
00:08:13.386 --> 00:08:15.058
Now I'm not suggesting you go out and
block Germany.

176
00:08:15.058 --> 00:08:19.140
I'm being very broad here because I know
there's some place out there with malware.

177
00:08:19.140 --> 00:08:22.390
I might be a little bit more succinct
if there was a place coming from

178
00:08:22.390 --> 00:08:24.400
Germany in my real
network that had malware.

179
00:08:24.400 --> 00:08:26.229
In this case here, I'm like,
hey, it was coming from Germany.

180
00:08:26.229 --> 00:08:29.888
I'm just going to Germany in a whole to
be able to create some vents for fun.

181
00:08:29.888 --> 00:08:33.672
All right, and we can only log in
the beginning because there is no end.

182
00:08:33.672 --> 00:08:35.878
And so, pretty simple guys, right?

183
00:08:35.878 --> 00:08:39.012

episodes.description: This episode walks the viewers through configuring a Network Discovery Policy and detecting network clients. Todd also demonstrates integrating with a Microsoft Active Directory and applying FireSIGHT recommendations in your IPS rules.

episodes.description: This video covers the reporting features in the FireSIGHT Management Center. Todd demonstrates creating templates, generating reports and scheduling reports, backups and more.
episodes.title: Reporting

We have this phenomenal report

episodes.description: This episode walks the viewer through the security event management features of Cisco FirePOWER. Todd demonstrates the threat dashboard and each of its components, including: connection events, malware events and event trajectory.
episodes.title: Event Analysis

episodes.description: Cisco FirePOWER is built on top of the powerful open source IPS suite Snort. This episode covers the preprocessors provided by Snort and shows how FirePOWER leverages them to detect and thwart attacks.

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd explains how Correlation Policies are used to connect users and computers to security events. He demonstrates how to configure correlation rules, set alerts, and configure remediation.
episodes.title: Correlation Policies

episodes.description: In part 2 of the Correlation Policy series, Todd walks the viewers through the final configuration stages. He explains how to use and configure white lists as well as traffic profiles. He ends the episode by tying it all together into a complete Correlation Policy.
episodes.title: Correlation Policies Part 2
